newsitem.title: FRANCE: France drops toughening of anti-racism law.
newsitem.headline: France drops toughening of anti-racism law.

text.p: The French government appeared on Tuesday to have shelved a bill to stiffen anti-racism laws as a response to far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen's public espousal of racial inequality.

The bill drafted by Justice Minister Jacques Toubon was conspicuously left out of the government-arranged agenda of the National Assembly (lower house) for the next six months as parliament reconvened after the New Year break.
"As you can see, there is no hurry," Michel Pericard, head of the ruling Gaullist RPR party in the assembly, told reporters.
The bill, widening the grounds for prosecution of racist statements and stiffening punishment, has been criticised as double-edged and opening the way to restriction of freedom of expression.
Toubon had tabled the bill last October to plug a loophole in laws punishing statements seen as inciting racial hatred.

He had said Le Pen, leader of the anti-immigrant National Front, could not be prosecuted for saying that racial inequality was a fact of life as the law only prohibits statements directed against a particular race group and does not cover general verbal attacks.
Under the proposed reform, an individual would no longer have to cite a particular religion or national or ethnic group to be prosecuted for a racist statement.

The measure would punish a racist statement by up to a year in prison and a fine of up to 300,000 francs ($60,000). Sanctions would increase to two years in jail and a 500,000 franc ($100,000) fine if the remark were judged an incitement to discrimination, hatred or violence.
